senses.de: To stop working after reaching a certain age
senses.ex: My father will retire when he turns 60

Tips.title: Career Conclusion
Tips.description: Used to signify ending a professional career, commonly due to age.
Tips.example: After 35 years, the teacher decided to retire.

Tips.title: Not Permanent
Tips.description: 'Retire' doesn't mean you can't work again. Some come out of retirement.
Tips.example: My aunt retired from teaching but tutors occasionally.

Tips.title: Planned Future
Tips.description: People often plan when they'll retire, considering personal and financial factors.
Tips.example: He's saving money so he can retire at 55.

Tips.title: Daily Routine
Tips.description: Retire' can refer to the habitual time you go to bed each night.
Tips.example: She retires by 10 pm to ensure she gets enough sleep.

Tips.title: Formal Expression
Tips.description: Using 'retire' for sleep is more formal and less common in casual talk.
Tips.example: The host suggested it was time we retired for the evening.

senses.de: To withdraw to a quiet or secluded place
senses.ex: After dinner, they retired to the living room for coffee

Tips.title: Seek Quiet
Tips.description: It means moving to a place where one can be peaceful or undisturbed.
Tips.example: After the guests left, we retired to the den to relax.

Tips.title: Temporary Seclusion
Tips.description: This use implies a temporary departure from a group for privacy or concentration.
Tips.example: Needing a break, she retired to her office.

senses.de: To take out of use or service
senses.ex: The airline has retired its old planes

Tips.title: End of Service
Tips.description: It describes the end of an item's operational life, often replaced by something newer.
Tips.example: The company retired the outdated software.

Tips.title: Not Just Tech
Tips.description: Although often used in a technical context, it also applies to non-tech items.
Tips.example: The navy retired the old battleship.

Abandon.wordDefinition:
Abandon means to completely give up or leave behind something or someone without any intention of returning.

It is generally used when someone or something is discarded or forsaken due to difficult circumstances. For example, abandoning a sinking ship or an abandoned house.

Abandon means to give up something or someone completely, while retire means to stop working or performing a specific job or duty after reaching a certain age or completing a period of service.

Depart.wordDefinition:
Depart refers to leaving or going away from a particular place or situation, while retire refers to leaving a job or career permanently or for an extended period of time.

For example, if someone is traveling and they say they are departing, it means they are leaving that place to go somewhere else.

Depart means leaving a place or situation, while retire means leaving a career or job permanently.

Give up.wordDefinition:
The words give up and retire both mean to stop doing something, but they are used in different situations.

Give up often implies quitting or surrendering when faced with a difficult situation or task. For example, if someone says "I give up" during a challenging game, it means they are no longer going to try.

Give up is a more general phrase that can be applied to any situation where someone stops trying to complete something, whereas retire specifically refers to stopping work and moving into a different lifestyle.

Quit.wordDefinition:
Quit generally means to leave a job or stop doing something without any particular plan for the future. This can happen for various reasons, such as dissatisfaction with the job or personal reasons.

In simpler terms, quit is used when someone abruptly stops doing something, while retire is used when someone plans to stop working at a certain age or after a certain period of time.

Resign.wordDefinition:
Resign refers to voluntarily leaving a job or position before the end of the contract or term. This can be done for various reasons such as personal or professional growth, dissatisfaction with the job, or moving on to another opportunity.

Resign is usually a choice made by an individual to move on from a job, while retire is often the result of reaching a certain age or completing a particular number of years of service.

Step down.wordDefinition:
The phrase step down means to resign or give up a position of authority or responsibility.

In simple terms, retiring is leaving a job after a long career, while stepping down is voluntarily giving up a higher position of power or responsibility.

Withdraw.wordDefinition:
Withdraw can refer to removing oneself from a certain situation, without necessarily ending one's involvement in that situation.

For example, someone might withdraw from a conversation, but still be present in the room.

Retire implies leaving an entire career or lifestyle behind, while withdraw refers to removing oneself from a specific situation or commitment.

Yield.wordDefinition:
Yield means to give way or surrender to something or someone. It is mostly applicable to situations where someone or something gives up control or power to another person or thing.

For example, a driver yielding to pedestrians or a country yielding to the demands of another nation.

In simpler terms, retire is used when talking about leaving work or a job after a certain age, while yield is used when someone gives up control or power to someone or something else.

videos.Text: So many of the commercials that come out there in the way of a message -- what's really being said? "Your life would be better if you could work a little less, didn't have to work so hard, got home a little earlier, could retire a little faster, punch out a little sooner." It's all in there, over and over, again and again. Washington?

videos.Text: It's also lifelong. It never ends. The people in our 75-year study who were the happiest in retirement were the people who had actively worked to replace workmates with new playmates. Just like the millennials in that recent survey, many of our men when they were starting out as young adults

quotes.Text: I prefer to win titles with the team ahead of individual awards or scoring more goals than anyone else. I'm more worried about being a good person than being the best football player in the world. When all this is over, what are you left with? When I retire, I hope I am remembered for being a decent guy.
quotes.Title: Argentinian Footballer
quotes.Name: Lionel Messi

quotes.Text: I retired simply because I didn't have the passion and motivation anymore; I was tired. At the time I thought, 'Well, I had a great time, there is the end.' At some moment, there is the right time to call it an end.
quotes.Title: German Celebrity
quotes.Name: Michael Schumacher

quotes.Text: When I was playing before I retired, I never really understood the appreciation and the respect that people gave me. People had treated me like a god or something, and that was very embarrassing.
quotes.Title: American Basketball Player
quotes.Name: Michael Jordan

quotes.Text: We rarely find anyone who can say he has lived a happy life, and who, content with his life, can retire from the world like a satisfied guest.
quotes.Title: Roman Poet
quotes.Name: Horace

quotes.Text: I don't ever see myself retiring totally from music, because I have a genuine love and passion for it.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Dr. Dre

quotes.Text: When a man fell into his anecdotage it was a sign for him to retire from the world.
quotes.Title: British Statesman
quotes.Name: Benjamin Disraeli

quotes.Text: I respect public employees and school teachers. They deserve a secure retirement.
quotes.Title: American Politician
quotes.Name: Gina Raimondo

quotes.Text: I made peace with retirement, but when you're a fighter, you're always a fighter.
quotes.Title: Brazilian Athlete
quotes.Name: Royce Gracie

quotes.Text: Retiring from writing is not to retire from life.
quotes.Title: English Writer
quotes.Name: Jim Crace

quotes.Text: I wish I hadn't said I'm going to retire.
quotes.Title: British Athlete
quotes.Name: Bradley Wiggins
